Milt,

Yes, I already knew about the Boone Collection and the rest of the
holdings of the Field Museum, as well as the fact that they're not on
display. I decided to take a pass on the Field for that reason.

I'll try to do a bit more prep work, cajoling, outright bribery and
judicious sake gifting next time I'm in the area and see if I can
manage to see the good stuff there or elsewhere.

Thanks for the info!

Best Regards, 

Andres Pedraza 

-----Original Message-----
From: bungotakadasword [mailto:MuramasaIII@...]

Subject: [nihontostudy] Re: Chicago



--- In nihontostudy@yahoogroups.com, "Matthew E. Hoyle" 
<matthewhoyle@w...> wrote:
> Ask "the infamous" Milt, he should know, since he lives in Chicago.
> 
>  Sujikabuto@a...
> 
> Matt
> 
>  
>since my name is specifically targeted , I have no choice but to 
comply.
We have the Art Institute if you are interested in Asian ceramics, 
Japanese ukiyo-e.

The Field Museum has a large holding of tsuba but they do not display 
them publicly.
We local yokels have a  respected old timer that can arrange private 
viewing .  No, not me, I am not that respectable.
Other than that, there are a few collectors scattered allover the 
landscape that may be willing to show you their stuffs but they have 
to know you well first, I reckon. Personally. my sword collection is  
low to mid range , no juyo.  A lot of rusty tsuba I am working on but 
I do say my hawk paintings are quite outstanding, 50 + now, not too 
shabby.90+ % edo period, Soga school, Kano school, Tosa school, I 
love them.

Milt
